title: 114_s1739
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truck Safety Act" and includes provisions on minimum amounts. The "Truck Safety Act" includes provisions on increasing the minimum level of financial responsibility for transporting property, with adjustments to be made annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The Secretary of Transportation is authorized to raise the minimum levels if deemed necessary after a notice and comment period. The Secretary can increase the minimum financial responsibility levels for property transportation if the current amount is insufficient to cover liability claims. The Secretary of Transportation must establish a rule requiring large motor vehicles to have collision avoidance technologies within 24 months of this Act. Performance standards will be set to prevent collisions, and the regulations will take effect 2 years after the final rule is published. The Secretary of Transportation will finalize regulations within a year to mandate speed limiting devices on motor vehicles over 26,000 pounds. Compliance reviews for high-risk carriers will also be conducted. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct compliance reviews on high-risk carriers to ensure safety. A report on the actions taken will be submitted to Congress within 180 days. Section 4138 of the Safe, Accountable, Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act is repealed. SEC. 6. DRIVER COMPENSATION. The Secretary of Transportation will require motor carriers to track on-duty time for employees paid non-hourly wages and compensate them separately for on-duty time at a rate not less than the Federal minimum wage. This requirement does not apply to employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement. Employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement, certified by the National Labor Relations Board, must be compensated for all on-duty time. This does not affect obligations under the Fair Labor Standards Act. SEC. 7. STUDY ON COMMERCIAL MOTOR VEHICLE DRIVER COMMUTING. The Administrator of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration will conduct a study on the effects of excessive commuting on safety and commercial motor vehicle driver fatigue. This study will consider the prevalence of excessive driver commuting, distances traveled, time spent commuting, impact on safety and driver fatigue, commuting practices, and relevant regulations and policies. The Administrator will conduct a study on excessive driver commuting's effects on safety and driver fatigue, considering distances traveled, time spent commuting, impact on safety, and relevant regulations. A report with findings and recommendations for regulatory action will be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
